discourse_list.title: [Informal Poll] Should We Create High-Dust, Lower-Stability Fee Vaults?

content.content: Should there be a second set of vaults for major collateral types that offers preferential terms for extremely large deposits? If, for example, a party wanted to mint 100,000,000 DAI, should they have access to a vault with marginally lower Stability Fee, perhaps 10 or 20 basis points? This would be restricted to high-volume users by having extremely high Dust values. The exact metrics of how high to set Dust and how much Stability Fee discount to offer would require input from Risk and Growth to offer opinions on what levels would be most useful while not expanding our risk exposure more than necessary. Why Do This? Recent months have seen a large number of institutions become involved in crypto assets. We need a product that specifically appeals to these customers who may be still exploring options for USD-pegged stablecoins. Also, it is presumed that extremely large vaults are likely managed by parties with formal risk management teams and processes, making them less likely to be liquidated in a disorderly downturn than a standard vault. This may or may not be true, but my presumption is that this type of user can help anchor our core business when it becomes volatile. This is an automated, permissionless way to provide a tool the Growth team or individual DAO members can point to that is designed for institutions and high-volume users. Risks The main risk is continued exposure to the collateral types we already accept, but with lower aggregate fees. There is also a risk of existing large users – of which there are a few – migrating to these lower fee vaults without an offsetting increase in business from new large users. Next Step If Signal Is Successful If this poll is successful with a majority in affirmation, the next step is to bring a proposal with more details after consultation with Growth about what levels would be likely useful, and with Risk about what the appropriate trade-offs should be for combinations of Dust and fee discounts. A formal signal request will follow after asking for some input from Growth, Risk, and any other needed stakeholders. To help provide a clear signal, please vote in the poll below. I will push forward with a formal request if >50% of responses are affirmative on/after May 29 (two weeks) edited for typos     Yes. Let’s get input from Risk and Growth and present specifics to act upon. No. This is not needed at this time. Abstain.     0 voters

Generally, we use onchain voting when setting specific parameters, or in some cases when proof of sentiment is needed on the blockchain. The reason I suggested this be an informal poll is because without parameters their support or opposition won’t prevent this from needing to be proposed onchain again when the execution is ready to be implemented.

content.content: PaperImperium:  Also, it is presumed that extremely large vaults are likely managed by parties with formal risk management teams and processes, making them less likely to be liquidated in a disorderly downturn than a standard vault. This may or may not be true, but my presumption is that this type of user can help anchor our core business when it becomes volatile.   I think this proposal is getting really close to something useful, but I don’t think large debt size is a good proxy for lower risk profile.  A large borrower should need to offer something more. This proposal seems to be target at large organizations, business, or institutions. Those entities may be willing to gain more favorable terms in exchange for giving up anonymity and permissionlessness. If a known institution wants to borrow 1 Billion Dai, MakerDAO could offer a vault with lower stability and/or lower collateralization ratio in exchange for legal recourse.  The borrow agrees that if the loan defaults and liquidations don’t cover the debt, they must cover the difference. MakerDAO can sue them for it. It would be a hybrid Real World Asset – A cryptocurrency vault but with legal recourse layered on top. Just being a giant borrower probably doesn’t make you less likely to abandon a loan if the collateral value falls below the debt size, but being a known entity who co-signs for the loan (and isn’t bankrupt) probably does. I’m a NO on this vote but would be a YES if MakerDAO can get legal recourse thrown in.
